sets.name: Nasty Plot
sets.description:
Ninetales is a niche wallbreaker in the RU tier; with access to Drought and good coverage, it sets up in front of Pokemon such as Registeel, Sylveon, and Roserade, and it can threaten a wide variety of Pokemon including Seismitoad, Metagross, and Steelix. However, it is weak when unboosted and faces competition from Chandelure, Toxtricity, and Volcanion. Solar Beam grants Ninetales a strong coverage option to muscle past bulky Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune. Toxic cripples incoming walls such as Incineroar and Snorlax, and also Noivern. Scorching Sands hits Dragalge, Chandelure, and Incineroar. Choice Specs is a good alternative item, but Choice Specs Ninetales gets worn down by entry hazards quickly and is very prediction-reliant.

Despite Ninetales's great power, it has trouble bypassing Snorlax, as it can tank any hit Ninetales dishes out, so Fighting-types such as Cobalion, Mienshao, and Heracross are good teammates. Ninetales in return can help deal with Doublade and bulky Fairy-types such as Galarian Weezing. Ninetales has trouble breaking Dragon-types such as Noivern and Dragalge; Fairy-types such as Togekiss, Sylveon, and Gardevoir deal with Noivern, while bulky Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross can handle both. Choice Scarf Gardevoir is notably an excellent teammate, as it also provides Healing Wish support late-game, whereas Ninetales can blow through bulky Steel-types such as Registeel and Doublade. Knock Off users such as Mienshao and Seismitoad can remove annoying items such as Assault Vest on Reuniclus, Heavy-Duty Boots on Noivern, and Leftovers on Snorlax. Entry hazard setters such as Registeel, Metagross, and Golisopod are great, as they help in wearing down walls. Golisopod is an exceptional partner, as it provides both Knock Off and Spikes support, and it switches into Ground-type moves. Seismitoad sets Stealth Rock and also uses Knock Off. Ninetales can form a semi-sun core with Shiftry, which has good offensive synergy with Ninetales and can provide Knock Off support, although the lack of sun turns can limit the pair's effectiveness.

Vileplume.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Physically Defensive
sets.description: Vileplume's reliable bulk and good defensive typing allow it to act as a switch-in to common pivots in RU such as Zarude and Mienshao, while its ability Effect Spore lets it pressure physical attackers such as Cobalion and Sharpedo. Unfortunately, Vileplume can get worn down quickly and is often forced to use its recovery to remain healthy, which gives openings to Pokemon it invites in like Toxtricity and common Flying-types such as Noivern and Crobat. Strength Sap is Vileplumeâ€™s main recovery move and allows it to lower the Attack stat of an opposing physical attacker. Corrosive Gas is used to remove important items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Choice items from Pokemon such as Cobalion, Crobat, and Toxtricity. Alternatively, Sleep Powder can be used to put common switch-ins such as Crobat and Noivern to sleep, generating free turns for itself and its teammates. An alternative EV spread of 252 HP / 144 Def / 112 SpD can be used to avoid a 4HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt. Vileplume is best suited for balance teams that need a check for prominent physical attackers such as Zarude and Mienshao. Due to Vileplume's weakness to Fire-types, bulky Water-types such as Suicune and Milotic can be great teammates. In return, Vileplume can handle offensive Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Raikou. Since Vileplume often invites in Flying-types like Crobat and Tornadus, checks to these Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Raikou are good partners. Registeel and Steelix also make great teammates for Vileplume, since they are able to check offensive Psychic-types such as Gardevoir and Necrozma. Since Vileplume often switches into pivots, taking damage from entry hazards can quickly wear it down and limit its defensive capabilities, so entry hazard removal from Togekiss or Crobat is important.

sets.name: Shell Smash Sweeper
sets.description:
Shell Smash Cloyster's ability to potentially break past its checks through flinches make it a threatening setup sweeper. It also takes advantage of teams relying on Seismitoad and Gastrodon as their bulky Water-type, as neither is a suitable Cloyster check. Rock Blast hits Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune neutrally, helping Cloyster beat them with flinches. It also hits Volcanion and can be used against other Fire-types like Incineroar and Chandelure. Hydro Pump is the preferred last move due to its greater damage against Steel-types such as Metagross, Cobalion, and Steelix. Liquidation can be used instead to OHKO Diancie and potentially 2HKO Registeel after Spikes damage while also giving Cloyster a more reliable Water-type STAB move. However, it makes Cloyster more reliant on breaking past the aforementioned Steel-types with flinches. King's Rock gives Cloyster's Icicle Spear and Rock Blast an effective 41% flinch chance. A Naive or Jolly nature should be used, as they allow +2 Cloyster to outrun Choice Scarf Mienshao. Explosion can be used to take down Water-types such as Milotic and Suicune for a teammate. Focus Sash can be used to almost guarantee setup, but this requires solid entry hazard removal, and Cloyster loses out on the ability to break past its checks with flinches. Life Orb is another item option that allows Cloyster to KO notable threats such as Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, Metagross, and Doublade at +2 without prior residual damage. Spikes allows Cloyster, which beats most Defoggers, to give value to its team in a matchup where it doesn't do much else. However, Spikes also forces Cloyster to ditch its Water-type STAB moves, which worsens its matchup against Steel-types significantly.

Cloyster's natural physical bulk is impressive even without investment and gives it some notable setup opportunities against Pokemon such as Darmanitan, Crobat lacking Taunt, and Mimikyu. Cloyster is potentially capable of breaking past its defensive answers with flinches, but this requires a fair bit of luck. Bulky Water- and Steel-types can halt Cloyster barring an ill-timed flinch, so efforts should be put into wearing these Pokemon down. Most of the tier's bulky Steel-types will get worn down by Spikes; offensive Metagross, Cobalion, and Doublade will be in KO range of +2 Hydro Pump after switching in with three layers of Spikes, while Liquidation variants will be able to reliably 2HKO Registeel after two layers. Therefore, Spikes setters like Klefki and Roserade are good teammates. Cloyster's ability to take advantage of Spikes and cause its targets to flinch makes it a great choice for hyper offense teams, as it can be a devastating wincon or a supportive wallbreaker for another sweeping teammate such as Necrozma, Mimikyu, or Polteageist. Cloyster is also capable of sweeping on standard offensive and bulky offensive teams. Teams utilizing Cloyster in this regard should attempt to wear down bulky Water- and Steel-types. Knock Off from the likes of Incineroar, Reuniclus, and Obstagoon can remove Leftovers from Pokemon like Registeel and Suicune, making it easier for Cloyster to break through them. Pivoting teammates, such as Mienshao, Incineroar, and Crobat, can get Cloyster into battle safely. Toxic from Diancie and Salazzle can help wear down Water-types to let Cloyster go wild late-game.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Alolan Marowak is a fearsome wallbreaker in RU that is also able to soft check many dangerous threats, such as Roserade, Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Cobalion, due to its Lightning Rod ability and typing. Unfortunately, Alolan Marowak struggles to find wallbreaking opportunities, and it is also revenge killed easily due to its low Speed stat, vulnerability to Stealth Rock, weaknesses to common types, and mediocre bulk. Swords Dance lets Alolan Marowak break through every wall in RU after one boost. Alternatively, Flame Charge alongside a Jolly nature can be used to prevent it from being outsped and revenge killed by Pokemon such as Guts Heracross, Chandelure, and Choice Band Tyrantrum after one boost. However, even after one boost, it is still slower than many common threats like Obstagoon, Mienshao, and Noivern. Earthquake 2HKOes Incineroar after Intimidate and provides a stronger hit against Volcanion and Diancie. However, Low Kick gets an OHKO on Obstagoon, hits Snorlax much harder, and deals more damage than Fire Punch to some bulky Steel-types, such as Registeel and Steelix.

An entry hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, or Togekiss is crucial to pair with Alolan Marowak, as every entry hazard, especially Stealth Rock, limits its ability to switch into the mentioned threats. Offensive pivots like Noivern, Xurkitree, and Raikou support Alolan Marowak with free switches into defensive Pokemon it defeats easily, such as Registeel, Assault Vest Reuniclus, and Cresselia. Roserade checks Water-types, Golisopod checks Ground-types like Flygon, and both provide Spikes support. In general, Alolan Marowak appreciates bulky teammates like Togekiss, Seismitoad, and Steelix, since it's easily revenge killed by many Pokemon due to its low base Speed and common weaknesses. Wish support from Togekiss and Sylveon helps Alolan Marowak to stay healthy. Powerful late-game cleaners like Choice Scarf Heracross and Choice Scarf Xurkitree appreciate Alolan Marowak's wallbreaking capabilities.

sets.name: Misty Terrain
sets.description:
Misty Explosion and Memento fulfill very similar roles on this set - preserving momentum. Misty Explosion isn't blocked by Clear Body and Taunt and is able to deal not-insignificant damage to many targets like Cobalion, Togekiss, and Gastrodon, while Memento helps sweepers that are often paired with Galarian Weezing set up uncontested. Taunt blocks Defog and setup attempts from Pokemon like Togekiss and Doublade, which could prevent Galarian Weezing's teammates from sweeping. To ensure Misty Terrain is active, the last moveslot is used for it, which helps against faster Defoggers like Crobat and Volcanion after using Taunt on them. Fire Blast is an alternative last move to chip Steel-types like Metagross and Doublade.

Galarian Weezing's Misty Terrain blocks status for grounded Pokemon, so it fits great on setup spam hyper offense. Dual screen setters like Ribombee and Vanilluxe are great teammates, as Ribombee also provides Sticky Web, while Vanilluxe has momentum and Aurora Veil. Sweepers that make Misty Terain worthwhile include Slurpuff, Polteageist, Necrozma, and Cloyster, to name a few. Cloyster and Necrozma are particularly good teammates because they set up on Pokemon that Galarian Weezing invites in, such as Ground-types and Steel-, and Psychic-types, respectively. Other sweepers like Weakness Policy Zarude and Rhyperior are able to use the weaknesses they share with Galarian Weezing to get boosts against common Pokemon like Cobalion and Flygon. However, due to Misty Terrain halving Dragon-type attacks' power, sweepers like Regidrago and Tyrantrum are hard to fit on teams with Galarian Weezing.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Galarian Weezing's immense physical bulk and good defensive typing make it a good check to common threats such as Zarude, Mienshao, and Heracross. Neutralizing Gas gives it a unique advantage in removing offensive abilites like Heracross's and Obstagoon's Guts, Mienshao's Regenerator, Darmanitan's Sheer Force, and Cloyster's Skill Link. Galarian Weezing's mediocre special bulk, lack of consistent recovery, and general passivity make it harder to support and fit on teams than its Fairy-type competition of Togekiss and Sylveon. Sludge Bomb is preferred over Sludge Wave for its higher chance of poisoning. Galarian Weezing can be used as a Defogger, though it dislikes Stealth Rock setters such as Necrozma, Cobalion, and Rhyperior. Toxic Spikes can be useful for crippling Pokemon such as Seismitoad, Milotic, and Diancie, but it's matchup-dependent due to the prevalence of Heavy-Duty Boots and the large amount of viable Poison- and Steel-types such as Roserade, Toxtricity, Cobalion, and Metagross. Pain Split gives Galarian Weezing a form of recovery, albeit an unreliable one. Will-O-Wisp burns threats such as Cobalion, Mienshao, and Cloyster. Corrosive Gas can be used to remove items from the likes of Seismitoad, Registeel, and Chandelure. Rest is a viable option on stall teams, but stall is a rather unreliable playstyle as a whole. Black Sludge is preferred to give Galarian Weezing more survivability. Rocky Helmet can be used to force more damage onto the likes of Zarude and Mienshao, but should only be used with dedicated Wish support. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to mitigate entry hazard damage, but it has the same recovery issue as Rocky Helmet.

Galarian Weezing can be used on balance and stall teams that cover for it sapping momentum and appreciate it checking big threats in Zarude, Mienshao, and Heracross. Pokemon such as Registeel, Porygon2, and Assault Vest Reuniclus can help against specially offensive threats to Galarian Weezing such as Salazzle, Raikou, Necrozma, and Toxtricity. Registeel and Porygon2 also appreciate Galarian Weezing switching into threatening Fighting-types. Zarude is capable of checking Psychic-types such as Starmie and Reuniclus as well as Ground-types such as Rhyperior and Golurk. Options such as Seismitoad, Suicune, and Volcanion are capable of taking on offensive Steel-types such as Cobalion and Metagross. Volcanion is also a capable Defogger, freeing up Galarian Weezing to run other moves, most notably Pain Split. Every Electric-type in the tier forces Galarian Weezing out, leading to free uses of Volt Switch. Seismitoad, Gastrodon, Rhyperior, and Steelix are viable Ground-type partners as a result. Wish passing from the likes of Umbreon is useful and practically mandatory on stall, as Galarian Weezing lacks reliable recovery. Variants running Toxic Spikes can be supported by bulky Calm Mind sweepers like Suicune. Threats to Poison-types such as Necrozma, Gardevoir, and Alolan Marowak are important on such teams.

Tangela.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Wall
sets.description: Tangela's good Defense and reliable typing combined with Eviolite allow it to be a good defensive wall in RU, letting it wall physical threats like Golurk and Swords Dance Rhyperior. Knock Off removes items such as Leftovers from Registeel to limit its recovery and Heavy-Duty Boots from Talonflame to make it no longer a switch-in to Tangela. Sludge Bomb hits opposing Grass-types. Synthesis can be very helpful against physical setup sweepers like Barbaracle and Bewear. Leech Seed is an alternative that works with Knock Off to let Tangela more easily pressure Steel-types like Metagross. Thanks to the roles compression Tangela provides as a wall, it can fit on both balance and stall teams. Tangela loves to have teammates that can handle Fire-types very well, such as Milotic and Seismitoad. Due to Tangela's poor Special Defense, it needs special walls like Porygon2 to counter strong special attackers. Since Tangela relies on Eviolite for bulk, Pokemon that can comfortably switch into Knock Off, such as Rest Suicune and Cobalion, are great partners.

sets.name: Wallbreaker
sets.description:
Starmie's expansive offensive movepool allows it to act as a powerful wallbreaker that can use super effective coverage and Analytic to break past usual Water-type checks. Hydro Pump is an option over Surf to maximize damage on neutral targets in exchange for accuracy, although missing is a concern due to Starmie's below-average bulk. Ice Beam hits Grass- and Dragon-types such as Zarude, Roserade, and Noivern. Grass Knot nails bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Seismitoad, and Suicune. Thunderbolt is an option that hits Volcanion and revenge kills Golisopod, although it misses out on Seismitoad and Gastrodon. Recover Starmie can take advantage of forced switches to regain health and continue firing off hits later. Psyshock provides ample neutral coverage and eases prediction, but has few targets. Rapid Spin is an option if a team desperately needs hazard removal, and it has the added benefit of potentially making Starmie a threatening cleaner.

Entry hazard setters such as Roserade, Necrozma, and Klefki can help Starmie pressure balance cores more easily. Pivots like Mienshao and Incineroar can bring it into Pokemon it threatens such as Diancie and Galarian Weezing. Other wallbreakers like Darmanitan and Calm Mind Raikou can form cores with Starmie to break down each other's checks in bulky Water- and Grass-types. Pokemon that deal with special blanket checks, like Umbreon and Porygon2, are appreciated. Pangoro, Obstagoon, and Heracross are good options. Finally, cleaners such as Sharpedo and Mimikyu can take advantage of the holes Starmie breaks into opponents' teams to sweep.

sets.name: Rapid Spin
sets.description:
The following set is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

Starmie can act as a consistent entry hazard remover due to its good matchups against common hazard setters such as Cobalion and Diancie. Psyshock improves Starmie's matchup against Dragalge and Roserade. Psychic can maintain coverage on them while 2HKOing Seismitoad with Life Orb and Analytic. Grass Knot nails Seismitoad, a prominent Stealth Rock setter, allowing Starmie to always remove hazards from it. Teleport and Flip Turn can be used to maintain momentum instead. Heavy-Duty Boots increases its longevity and doesn't let it get poisoned by Toxic Spikes, although Life Orb can be used instead for more damage. Similarly, Analytic is a free damage boost on switches, but Natural Cure prevents Starmie from being crippled or worn down by paralysis, poison from Toxic Spikes if it runs Life Orb, and other status effects.

Starmie fits well with Pokemon that appreciate hazards being removed, such as Xurkitree, Darmanitan, and Roserade. Spikes setters like Roserade, Dragalge, and Klefki appreciate hazard removal that doesn't remove their hazards. Other potential hazard removers such as Togekiss and Noivern appreciate being able to run other moves. Finally, reliable answers to Zarude like Togekiss and Cobalion are necessary, as this set is particularly vulnerable to it.

sets.name: All-out Attacker
sets.description:
Tauros has a niche in RU as a strong wallbreaker because of its great Speed and Attack stats combined with its all-around perfect coverage and ability in Sheer Force. However, Tauros lacks the raw strength of other wallbreakers such as Mienshao, Heracross, and Obstagoon, and its low special bulk leaves it vulnerable to common special attackers like Noivern and Raikou. Close Combat hits targets that resist Tauros's powerful STAB Body Slam such as Cobalion, Registeel, and Stakataka. Throat Chop hits Pokemon that are immune to Body Slam, such as Dhelmise, Golurk, and Doublade. Rock Slide enables Tauros to catch Flying-types such as Togekiss, Noivern, and Talonflame while hitting Pokemon like Golisopod super effectively. Tauros has the option to run Earthquake to 2HKO Diancie and Neutralizing Gas Galarian Weezing, but it has no other notable targets that aren't already covered. Protect is another option to block First Impression from Golisopod and scout Choice-locked foes such as Mienshao and Xurkitree, but Tauros would miss out on coverage as a result.

Like most wallbreakers, Tauros appreciates Spikes support from Roserade and Golisopod to limit its checks from switching in such as Cobalion and Milotic; Golisopod can also remove key items such as Leftovers, Heavy-Duty Boots, and Choice Scarf from Gastrodon, Togekiss, and Mienshao. Potent Fighting-types such as Choice Scarf Heracross and Mienshao pose as fierce revenge killers, so teammates such as Noivern and Togekiss are helpful. Additionally, Noivern, Raikou, and Choice Scarf Xurkitree can all force Tauros out, so special walls such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Steelix, and Registeel are always helpful. Pivots such as Raikou, Noivern, and Incineroar also serve as good teammates, as they provide free switches for Tauros. Raikou can also pressure bulky Water-types and cripple Tauros's switch-ins such as Gastrodon and Tangela with Toxic. In return, Tauros is able to weaken Grass- and Ground-types such as Vileplume, Seismitoad, and Steelix with Body Slam and Close Combat for Raikou.

sets.name: Revenge Killer
sets.description:
Ditto is a reliable revenge killer with good offensive matchups, since it's able to revenge kill Pokemon like Swords Dance Cobalion and Shell Smash Cloyster. It also has a good stall matchup because it can infinitely replenish PP and copy utility moves. Ditto's EVs just maximize its physical bulk and minimize Speed in case of the rare Ditto mirror matchup, while the Impish nature and 4 Speed IVs with a Choice Scarf allow it to outspeed Galarian Weezing, which can block Imposter by activating Neutralizing Gas. An alternative spread with 0 Speed IVs and a Relaxed nature maximizes Ditto's chances of winning mirror matchups.

Ditto can fit on a team mainly looking for a revenge killer to deal with a range of threats that cannot be walled by a single Pokemon and could break through the team. Thus, it's a solid pick with a defensive backbone. In return, defensive teammates can switch into offensive foes for it. Ditto can also fit on offensive teams that have very little defensive backbone, revenge killing threats that could run through the team and patching up the stall matchup. Ditto in turn appreciates offensive breakers such as Toxtricity and Heracross helping its shaky matchup against balance teams. It also needs teammates that can beat Substitute users like Suicune and Volcanion; countermeasures to these Pokemon include Infiltrator Pokemon such as Toxic Crobat and Noivern. Entry hazard removers like Togekiss can also be helpful for Ditto to reliably switch into threats. Cleric support from Pokemon like Umbreon and Sylveon prevents Toxic from stopping Ditto against stall teams. Finally, Knock Off absorbers like Bewear and Cobalion can be vital, as Ditto losing its Choice Scarf means it will be unable to revenge kill offensive threats.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Omastar has a niche in RU as a strong Shell Smash sweeper on rain teams. However, it struggles to find setup opportunities due to its typing and poor Special Defense, and even with boosts, it still slightly struggles to break through some bulky Pokemon such as Assault Vest Reuniclus, Gastrodon, and Snorlax. Meteor Beam OHKOes bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Suicune, and Volcanion after Shell Smash boosts, which otherwise check Omastar well. Surf is the preferred STAB move when Omastar is used on rain teams. Hydro Pump, on the other hand, is the better choice on hyper offense due to its higher Base Power, allowing Omastar to OHKO bulky Metagross and offensive Necrozma as well as 2HKO Registeel and Snorlax. Ice Beam OHKOes many Dragon- and Grass-types such as Noivern, Celebi, and Roserade, as well as Dragalge and Toxicroak after some chip damage.

Politoed is a necessary teammate if Omastar is used on rain teams. Seismitoad and Kingdra are strong rain sweepers, which help Omastar to overwhelm bulky Pokemon such as Milotic, Registeel, and Assault Vest Reuniclus. In addition, Seismitoad also provides Stealth Rock support and an immunity to Electric-type moves. Tornadus, Raikou, Metagross, and Toxicroak are other examples that work well on rain teams and help Omastar to break through opposing teams.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kabutops is a niche but potent rain attacker with access to Swords Dance that can hit most rain checks like Gastrodon neutrally. Liquidation is stronger than Waterfall, but Waterfall can give unexpected openings through flinches. Superpower lets Kabutops break past Gastrodon and Seismitoad if they are chipped, while Aqua Jet can clean even if rain runs out. Protect can be used to prevent First Impression.

Kabutops should always be run with Politoed on dedicated rain teams. Other rain sweepers such as Kingdra, Nasty Plot Tornadus, and Seismitoad can work in tandem with Kabutops to wear down the opposing team's defensive structure. Checks to opposing Gastrodon and defensive variants of Seismitoad, such as Tornadus and Ludicolo, are necessary, as Kabutops is completely walled by them. Other Pokemon that fit on rain teams like Klefki, Toxicroak, and Raikou also pair well with Kabutops.

sets.name: Dragon Dance
sets.description:
Dragon Dance allows Aerodactyl to function as a dangerous setup sweeper. One boost from Dragon Dance lets Aerodactyl OHKO threats like Zarude while being faster than most Choice Scarf users, including Zarude and Mienshao. Earthquake hits Steel-types like Steelix, Stakataka, and Metagross that resist both STAB moves. Life Orb is preferred, but Heavy-Duty Boots does grant Aerodactyl Stealth Rock immunity and lacks Life Orb's recoil, which makes setting up easier. An Adamant nature lets Aerodactyl hit harder, while a Jolly nature lets it outspeed Noivern unboosted. Unnerve prevents threats like Cobalion from using their Shuca Berry and eating up an Earthquake.

Bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad eat up Aerodactyl's moves and check it, so teammates like Zarude, Roserade, and Toxtricity are appreciated. Zarude serves as a Scald switch-in that can heal itself with Jungle Healing while pivoting out on a Togekiss switch-in for Aerodactyl. Roserade provides Spikes support to wear down said Water-types as well as a super effective STAB Leaf Storm. Despite Earthquake being able to hit them, Steel-types like Doublade, Steelix, and Registeel can be problematic. Teammates like Incineroar, Milotic, and Heracross handle them with minimal fuss. A partner like Obstagoon or Choice Specs Gardevoir can wear down Steel-types to put them in OHKO range of Aerodactyl's attacks. Teammates like Dhelmise and Registeel that appreciate Aerodactyl pressuring threats like Noivern, Chandelure, and Fighting-types work as partners. Dhelmise is notable because it provides Rapid Spin support for Aerodactyl using Life Orb. Other notable entry hazard control teammates include Starmie and Volcanion to check threats like Rhyperior.

sets.name: 3 Attacks + Roost
sets.description: Aerodactyl's natural Speed and Attack stats also make it a decent choice for an anti-offense Pokemon, outspeeding common threats like Noivern and Raikou. Earthquake guarantees OHKOs on Electric-types like Xurkitree and Toxtricity while guaranteeing 2HKOs on Steel-types like Metagross and Stakataka. Roost gives Aerodactyl reliable recovery to make up for Life Orb recoil and potential Stealth Rock chip if it's not carrying Heavy-Duty Boots. Teammates like Galarian Weezing and Volcanion can provide Defog support while also checking threats like Choice Scarf Mienshao and bulkier Steel-types, respectively. Dhelmise, Roserade, and Xurkitree can deal with bulky Water-types like Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad that give Aerodactyl a hard time. Dhelmise provides Rapid Spin support, while Roserade provides Spikes support to further wear down Aerodactyl's checks. Teammates like Zarude and Cobalion that can bring in Aerodactyl safely to beat Togekiss and Chandelure, respectively, are appreciated. Choice Scarf users like Xurkitree, Darmanitan, and the aforementioned Mienshao OHKO Aerodactyl. Therefore, teammates like Assault Vest Reuniclus, Milotic, and Galarian Weezing are useful to check these threats.

sets.name: Curselax
sets.description:
Snorlax's overall bulk and access to Curse enable it to check Fire- and Electric-types such as Chandelure, Darmanitan, and Raikou. However, Snorlax's typing leaves it with no resistances, making it unable to switch into powerful Pokemon such as Choice Specs Toxtricity and Indeedee-M. Curse enables Snorlax to have immense sweeping potential while also letting it threaten its checks. Body Slam inflicts paralysis, making it easier for Snorlax to get boosts from Curse while helping its teammates by slowing down faster threats. Earthquake provides great coverage against Normal-resistant and -immune Pokemon like Cobalion and Alolan Marowak. Rest is Snorlax's main recovery move while also being able to remove status effects. Thick Fat enables Snorlax to reliably switch into Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion. 12 HP EVs slightly increase recovery from Leftovers. Snorlax can opt for a spread of 12 HP / 116 Atk / 204 Def / 176 SpD to OHKO Cobalion with Earthquake after a Curse and a Defense drop from Close Combat and evade a 3HKO from Xurkitree's Thunderbolt and Volcanion's Steam Eruption. Alternatively, Snorlax can use a spread of 184 HP / 72 Def / 252 SpD to avoid a 2HKO from Choice Specs Toxtricity's Boomburst after Stealth Rock.

Snorlax usually prefers to be on balanced and bulky offensive teams due to it checking major wallbreakers like Chandelure and its sweeping potential. Snorlax's weakness to Fighting-type attacks means it appreciates having Fairy-types teammates like Galarian Weezing, Gardevoir, and Togekiss. Galarian Weezing is particularly useful for switching into Guts Heracross, which can threaten to OHKO Snorlax even after a Curse. Cleric support from the likes of Sylveon and Umbreon is very helpful if Snorlax is forced out after using Rest. Snorlax enjoys having Toxic Spikes support from Dragalge and Galarian Weezing since it can pressure bulky Waters-types like Haze Milotic. Knock Off users like Incineroar and Obstagoon make great teammates because they are able to remove valuable items like Heavy-Duty Boots and Leftovers, making it easier for Snorlax to beat its checks such as Haze Milotic and Rhyperior. Snorlax likes to have Dark-type Pokemon such as Zarude and Drapion as teammates since they are able to check Ghost-types like Mimikyu and Doublade.

Crobat.overview: Crobat's great defensive typing provides it with many notable resistances and an immunity, which enables it to check premier threats such as Roserade, Heracross, and Mienshao. Its high Speed stat and use of Heavy-Duty Boots provide it with many opportunities to clear away entry hazards with Defog and pivot out of unfavourable matchups with U-turn. Crobat also has the potential to run stallbreaking sets that can bypass Pokemon like Cobalion, Milotic, and Sylveon. Crobat depends upon Heavy-Duty Boots for most of its defensive utility and is vulnerable to Knock Off from Mienshao and Heracross. Crobat also has a tough matchup against common Stealth Rock setters like Metagross, Stakataka, Seismitoad, and Necrozma, which prevent it from being able to consistently remove Stealth Rock. Crobat is very suspectible to Electric-types like Raikou, Xurkitree, and Heliolisk, and it faces stiff competition with Noivern, which can chip Steel-types like Steelix and Metagross with Flamethower and use Draco Meteor against prominent Electric-types such as Raikou, Xurkitree, and Toxtricity.
Crobat.comments:
Other Options

Super Fang turns Crobat into a stallbreaker that can wear down bulky Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross. Poison Fang can chip down Electric-types as well as Togekiss while having the possibility to weaken checks with Toxic. Nasty Plot can be run alongside special moves such as Sludge Bomb, Hurricane, Heat Wave, and Giga Drain to pressure checks to physical Crobat like Steelix and Seismitoad, but Crobat's Special Attack is very mediocre, leaving it outclassed by other special sweepers like Nasty Plot Togekiss and Reuniclus.

Checks and Counters

Super Effective Attackers: Common Electric- and Rock-types such as Raikou, Xurkitree, and Diancie resist Brave Bird and can easily KO Crobat with their STAB moves.

Faster Threats: Choice Scarf users such as Tyrantrum, Darmanitan, and Gardevoir can easily threaten Crobat by KOing it or pivoting as it's forced out.

Steel-types: Steel-types such as Metagross, Steelix, and Stakataka are only bothered by Super Fang and can use Crobat to set Stealth Rock up.

Bulky Setup Pokemon: Crobat struggles with breaking past bulky Pokemon like Reuniclus, RestTalk variants of Suicune, and Snorlax, though they donâ€™t appreciate being hit with Taunt.

sets.name: Pivot
sets.description:
U-turn capitalizes on Crobat's high Speed stat and keeps momentum for the team. Defog helps provide Crobat's team with entry hazard control. Alternatively, Taunt can be run to shut down defensive Pokemon like Body Press Registeel and Sylveon. Toxic can be used in conjunction with Taunt at the sacrifice of U-turn to wear down Pokemon like Milotic, Seismitoad, and Umbreon.

Crobat fits mainly on bulky offense and balance teams, which benefit from its natural longevity from Heavy-Duty Boots and ability to keep up momentum for its team. Wallbreakers such as Chandelure, Heracross, and Toxtricity can take advantage of U-turn and force out many of Crobat's checks, including Nasty Plot Togekiss, Reuniclus, and Diancie. Ground-types such as Steelix and Flygon prevent Electric-types such as Raikou, and Xurkitree from constantly gaining momentum with Volt Switch, while Crobat can take care of common Grass- and Fighting-types like Roserade, Mienshao, and Heracross. Crobat still struggles against bulky Steel-types like Seismic Toss Registeel, Steelix, and Metagross, so partners like Milotic and Seismitoad are beneficial. Knock Off absorbers like Cobalion help neuter Crobat's weakness to the move. Other pivots like Mienshao, Raikou, Darmanitan, and Xurkitree can form a VoltTurn core to create momentum for Crobat's team and benefit from hazards being removed so they can constantly pivot around.

sets.name: Magic Bounce
sets.description:
Magic Bounce comes in handy for reflecting status moves such as Toxic and most importantly Stealth Rock from Pokemon such as Registeel and Steelix. Heat Wave allows Xatu to hit Steel-types like Klefki and Metagross. Giga Drain 2HKOes Seismitoad and chips away at Diancie. Teleport's negative priority allows Xatu to bring teammates in safely, but U-turn can be ran to avoid additional damage when pivoting. Rocky Helmet is a great item on Xatu because it helps to pressure Steel-type Stealth Rock setters such as Cobalion, Metagross, and Registeel. Heavy-Duty Boots is also a useful item because Xatu is not going to be able to deflect Stealth Rock from certain Stealth Rock setters, such as Stakataka and the occasional Gigalith, therefore, Heavy-Duty Boots is needed to not get chipped by their entry hazards when pivoting. Max Defense lets Xatu take two Meteor Mash from Metagross. Speed investment makes it less reliable against Metagross, but outspeeding Roserade can be useful for some teams.

Due to the great roles that Xatu provides as a defensive pivot, it can fit on balance or bulky teams. Xatu likes to have offensive pivots as teammates, such as Darmanitan and Xurkitree, which appreciate Magic Bounce keeping entry hazards off the field so they can be more reliable pivots. Fairy-type Pokemon such as Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing can be very helpful teammates since they are able to check Dark-type Pokemon such as Obstagoon and Incineroar. Meanwhile, specially defensive walls like Steelix and Porygon2 appreciate hazard prevention, since then they can check Electric-types such as Xurkitree and Toxtricity more reliably.

sets.name: Rain Setter
sets.description:
Politoed enables a powerful but matchup-reliant archetype in rain due to being the only Drizzle Pokemon in the tier. However, outside of setting rain, Politoed is a generally underwhelming Pokemon that canâ€™t provide much help to rain teams itself and often becomes a momentum sink due to its passiveness. Encore allows it to deal with bulkier threats that would wall it otherwise and discourage Pokemon from setting up on it. Toxic can break down walls in tandem with Encore, particularly bulky Water-types that pose a threat to rain teams like Seismitoad. Hypnosis trades some effectiveness against passive builds for the potential to shut down common roadblocks to rain teams like Gastrodon and Milotic, and maintain utility against more offensive teams looking to take advantage of Politoedâ€™s passivity. Ice Beam chips Grass-types like Celebi, 3HKOes Dragalge, and OHKOes Noivern with the Special Attack investment. Perish Song forces bulky setup sweepers out, allowing Politoed to check Pokemon like Suicune, Snorlax, and Reuniclus. Finally, Rest allows Politoed to continue setting rain when severely weakened and in long matches against passive teams. Non-Ice Beam variants can invest the 76 Special Attack EVs into Defense, as they do nothing significant with Scald. 56 Speed EVs let Politoed outrun Alolan Marowak, but 92 Speed EVs can be ran for Milotic, which Encore + Toxic variants can beat.

Politoedâ€™s only niche is setting rain, so Pokemon that take advantage of it are necessary. Swift Swim Pokemon like Kingdra, Omastar, and Kabutops can offensively pressure the opponent and sweep once they are weakened. Seismitoad can also provide an Electric immunity and Stealth Rock. Electric-types of your own like Raikou and Heliolisk are able to run Thunder and Weather Ball as coverage and check Electric- or Water-types. Tornadus also enjoys fully accurate Hurricane and Weather Ball coverage. Toxicroak appreciates the Dry Skin recovery and can switch into Milotic with impunity. Steel-types like Metagross and Steelix can provide good defensive utility for rain teams. Finally, entry hazard setters such as Klefki and Roserade can help pressure bulkier cores that threaten rain such as Suicune + Assault Vest Reuniclus, as well as synergizing with the surprising amount of switches Politoed can force from defensive Pokemon.

sets.name: Cleric
sets.description:
Umbreon's ability to support other teammates and check strong special attackers such as Chandelure, Indeedee-M, and Necrozma gives it a significant niche in RU. Bulky PokÃ©mon without a reliable recovery move appreciate Umbreon keeping them healthy with Wish and Heal Bell. Protect allows Umbreon to safely recover with Wish and scout opposing Choice item Pokemon. If another teammate already has Heal Bell or Aromatherapy, Umbreon can use Toxic to weaken opposing PokÃ©mon. Foul Play is Umbreon's most reliable offensive move and helps it to better deal with physical attackers such as Metagross, Alolan Marowak, and Crobat. The given EVs coupled with a Calm nature allow Umbreon to check special attackers more effectively. Leftovers gives Umbreon passive recovery and works nicely with Protect. However, Heavy-Duty Boots can be used to prevent entry hazard damage, as this cuts into Umbreon's longevity and forces it to use Wish itself more often.

Galarian Weezing is a phenomenal partner for Umbreon because it covers Umbreon's weaknesses, checks common Fighting-types and powerful physical attackers such as Mienshao, Heracross, and Obstagoon, and removes entry hazards with Defog. In return, Umbreon covers Galarian Weezing's weakness to Psychic-type moves and, more importantly, keeps it healthy with its Wish support. Doublade is another example that has good defensive synergy with Umbreon. In general, many defensive and bulky Pokemon without reliable recovery and with susceptibility to status moves, such as Seismitoad, Diancie, and Steelix, appreciate Umbreon as a teammate. Furthermore, if Umbreon is not running Heavy-Duty Boots, a hazard remover like Noivern or Togekiss is very helpful. Since Umbreon is a very passive PokÃ©mon, bulky setup sweepers like Calm Mind Suicune, Curse Snorlax and Nasty Plot Togekiss can take advantage of it. Powerful attackers like Heracross and Choice Specs Toxtricity can deal with these threats. Lastly, although Umbreon is a good special wall, some special attackers like Nasty Plot Salazzle and Choice Specs Gardevoir can overwhelm Umbreon quickly. Diancie and Registeel can deal with these threats defensively, while faster Pokemon like Crobat and Choice Scarf Flygon check them offensively.

Steelix.overview: Steelix's natural bulk, defensive typing, and multiple utility options make it an excellent Stealth Rock setter for balanced or bulky offensive teams. Its solid typing blocks Volt Switch from common Electric-types while also packing a Toxic immunity, something no other Stealth Rock user can offer. Additionally, it serves as a check to common threats like Sylveon, Xurkitree, Toxtricity, Registeel, and Metagross. However, some Electric- and Fairy-types, such as Raikou, Gardevoir, and Togekiss, commonly carry coverage moves that Steelix is vulnerable to. Steelix also struggles with common Water-types like Seismitoad, Milotic, and Volcanion, and its Grass neutrality makes it a Steel-type that cannot reliably check threats like Zarude and Roserade.
Steelix.comments:
Other Options

Iron Defense + Body Press can handle threats like Curse Snorlax reliably. However, another move must be sacrificed for Iron Defense, and dropping Earthquake leaves Steelix susceptible to Electric-types. Dragon Tail or Roar could be thrown in for setup sweepers like Curse Gastrodon, Reuniclus, and Suicune. Unfortunately, the moves force Steelix to move last, so it can end up getting KOed by Scald or Focus Blast.

Checks and Counters

Water-types: Milotic, Seismitoad, and Suicune barely take any damage from Steelix's moves and only worry about Toxic, which Suicune can cure with Rest.

Ground-types: Rhyperior and Gastrodon offensively pressure Steelix. They don't want to be hit with Toxic, however.

Fighting-types: Mienshao and Heracross can pick off weakened Steelix with Close Combat.

Bulky Setup Sweepers: Magic Guard Reuniclus, Suicune, and Snorlax don't mind switching into Toxic and freely set up on Steelix.

Fire-types: Chandelure, Volcanion, and Darmanitan force Steelix out with ease. They need to beware of Earthquake from Sturdy variants, however.

sets.name: Defensive
sets.description:
Heavy Slam reliably beats Sylveon, OHKOes Gardevoir, and 2HKOes Togekiss. Toxic puts common switch-ins to Steelix, like Milotic and Seismitoad, under pressure. The last moveslot is fairly flexible. Body Press, for example, allows Steelix to 2HKO Zarude and OHKO Obstagoon. Head Smash coupled with Rock Head can catch Crobat and Noivern off guard and force them to use Roost.

Since this set focuses on checking foes, setting up Stealth Rock, and providing Toxic support for balanced or bulky offensive teams, Steelix is forced out by numerous threats, including Ground-types like Rhyperior and Gastrodon. Because of this, teammates like Zarude, Togekiss, and Milotic are appreciated. Milotic can switch into any of the Ground-types. Common Water-types like Milotic, Seismitoad, and Suicune force Steelix out or cripple it. Xurkitree, Raikou, Roserade, and the aforementioned Zarude work as answers to them. Zarude is notable because it can pivot on Fairy-types, while Roserade can provide Spikes support, put more pressure on Togekiss, and check Raikou. Xurkitree can threaten other Ground-types with Energy Ball. Fire-types like Chandelure and Volcanion also offensively pressure Steelix, so partners like Incineroar and Noivern are greatly appreciated. Fighting-types like Heracross and Mienshao appreciate Steelix checking Fairy-types that they struggle with. Fairy-type partners like Sylveon and Galarian Weezing are appreciated, since Sylveon can provide Wish support as well as check threats like Toxtricity if need be, while Galarian Weezing works well as a switch-in to Fighting-types as well as Zarude and can provide Defog support. A teammate like Crobat or Darmanitan can scare off Grass-types like Zarude and Roserade, which Steelix is not a reliable switch-in or check to.

Heracross.overview: Guts Heracross stands as one of the most dangerous wallbreakers thanks to its freedom to choose between powerful attacks alongside its decent Speed tier, which lets it outspeed bulkier Pokemon and keep dangerous threats like Volcanion and Toxtricity in check. Heracross's typing enables it to take a hit from Zarude or Mienshao, giving it openings and expanding its defensive use. Meanwhile, Choice Scarf allows Heracross to act as a revenge killer and a potent cleaner, with Moxie allowing it to snowball after a KO. Despite Heracross's potency in wallbreaking, the Guts set cannot come onto the field easily by itself and is quickly worn down by entry hazards and its burn, mandating support and selective play. The Choice Scarf set requires the opposition to be heavily weakened to sweep and struggles with faster Choice Scarf users that can revenge kill it, especially if it lowers its defenses with Close Combat. Mienshao competes with it as a Choice Scarf Fighting-type, as it is faster, can pivot around with U-turn, and has Regenerator to combat chip damage, but Mienshao cannot snowball like Heracross can.
Heracross.comments:
Other Options

Choice Band is an alternative wallbreaking route that is able to stay healthy more easily while potentially bluffing a Choice Scarf set, but it is held back by its prediction-reliant nature in an environment with Pokemon like Togekiss, Crobat, and Alolan Marowak, which can sponge its STAB attacks.

Checks and Counters

Fairy-types: Even though Fairy-types like Togekiss, Sylveon, and Galarian Weezing are threatened by Facade from the Guts set, they can prove to be an annoyance if Heracross doesn't predict correctly. Galarian Weezing in particular does well if carrying Neutralizing Gas to negate Guts. Choice Scarf Heracross severely struggles with Fairy-types, as it has no direct workaround for most of them.

Faster Pokemon: Many threats such as Starmie, Obstagoon, Talonflame, and Mimikyu can outpace and threaten Guts Heracross. Choice Scarf Heracross can take a hit from certain Choice Scarf users, such as Zarude and Mienshao, but others like Darmanitan outspeed and KO it. If Heracross drops its defenses with Close Combat, more Pokemon are capable of revenge killing it even at high health.

sets.name: Guts Wallbreaker
sets.description: Megahorn OHKOes Psychic-types like Reuniclus, Cresselia, and Necrozma, while Swords Dance can ease prediction against Fairy-types and punish Protect users trying to rack up Flame Orb chip. Stone Edge can snipe Flying-types such as Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame, which can otherwise take a hit and threaten Heracross out. Heracross puts immediate pressure on Steel-types and often zeroes in on Fairy-types such as Togekiss and Sylveon, which Zarude and Sharpedo can take advantage of. Heracross can break through most Pokemon by itself, but teammates like Starmie can prevent chip damage from entry hazards and pivots such as Thundurus and Darmanitan give Heracross openings to activate its Flame Orb, maximizing its chances to wallbreak. Certain Pokemon like Chandelure, Galarian Weezing, and Mimikyu can attempt to pivot around Heracross's attacks, racking up Flame Orb damage and punishing mispredictions, so having teammates like Darmanitan can help apply additional pressure on them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description: Megahorn is a strong secondary STAB attack to clean with, but Spikes can be more effective against bulkier teams. Stone Edge allows Heracross to keep Crobat, Noivern, and Talonflame in check and potentially catch Togekiss attempting to switch in. The threat of a late-game sweep will require the opponent to preserve a set of Pokemon in order to handle any one move Heracross may try to clean with. Thus, partners like Obstagoon and Gardevoir can help wear down or threaten these Pokemon, which include Chandelure, Doublade, and Togekiss. Heracross's weakness to faster Choice Scarf users like Darmanitan can be mitigated by teammates like Rhyperior and Seismitoad, which can also set up Stealth Rock to chip away at the opposition. Running Spikes on Heracross not only helps its own sweeping efforts, but also assists other Pokemon like Stakataka and Necrozma, which benefit from Steel- and Water-types being worn down.

sets.name: Rain Sweeper
sets.description:
Kingdra's all-around good stats and access to Swift Swim make it an excellent choice on rain teams. Hurricane is used so that Kingdra can beat Grass-type Pokemon like Roserade without Draco Meteor Special Attack drops. Hydro Pump's main use over the more accurate Surf is to 2HKO even dedicated special walls like Registeel, Umbreon, and Assault Vest Reuniclus in rain; Surf is already powerful enough to OHKO most offensive Pokemon it hits neutrally. Flip Turn can be used instead to grab momentum off of Kingdra's checks and ease prediction for Choice Specs sets. Life Orb is the preferred item because it boosts power without locking Kingdra into one move; however, Choice Specs gives Kingdra the best chance to 2HKO bulky Water-types like Suicune and Milotic with Draco Meteor while also avoiding Life Orb's chip damage. Kingdra can opt for a Timid nature in order to outpace Choice Specs Gardevoir, which copies its Swift Swim with Trace, and improve its matchups against the likes of Togekiss and Chandelure out of rain.

Kingdra must always be supported by Drizzle from Politoed to activate Swift Swim. Without Drizzle support, Kingdra is outclassed by other offensive Water-type Pokemon like Starmie. Kingdra works best when used alongside other rain sweepers. Kabutops, Omastar, and Seismitoad can weaken bulky Water-type Pokemon like Milotic and Suicune. Heliolisk blocks Water-type moves from the aforementioned Pokemon and threatens them with Thunder, making it an especially good Kingdra partner. In a similar vein, Tornadus benefits from Kingdra's Flip Turn to come in safely and break down bulky Water-type Pokemon.

sets.name: Specially Defensive
sets.description:
Porygon2 is one of the tier's better defensive pivots thanks to its great support movepool, Eviolite-boosted bulk, and amazing ability. Teleport allows Porygon2 to reliably get in powerful wallbreakers while sparing them from taking direct damage. Ice Beam is generally the preferred attacking move because it OHKOes Noivern and Flygon, while also 2HKOing Roserade and Golurk. Tri Attack is a decent alternative that does more to the likes of Xurkitree, Raikou, and Toxtricity. Toxic cripples the likes of Milotic, Volcanion, and Raikou, mitigating their long-term impact against Porygon2's teammates. Foul Play is an attacking option to hit Metagross and Alolan Marowak, while also letting Porygon2 check Polteageist much easier. A specially defensive spread allows Eviolite Porygon2 to blanket check many dangerous special attackers, such as Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Roserade. Some Defense investment can be used to make Porygon2 a better pivot into the likes of Dhelmise and Flygon should its team need it. Trace allows Porygon2 to copy great abilities, like Regenerator from Reuniclus and Punk Rock from Toxtricity.

Porygon2 pairs very well with most offensive Pokemon, as it's able to absorb damage and switch them in safely with Teleport. Toxtricity, Darmanitan, Mienshao, and Heracross are powerful wallbreakers that enjoy having Porygon2 to fall back on when they're forced out by certain special attackers, such as Noivern. A pivoting core can also be powerful, especially with the likes of Mienshao, Incineroar, and Raikou, as it can keep Porygon2 in favorable situations. Incineroar deserves special mention because Intimidate helps it to stomach physical attacks for Porygon2, though it doesn't appreciate Knock Off removing its Heavy-Duty Boots. Togekiss and Galarian Weezing are great checks to Fighting-types while Porygon2 can easily handle most Toxtricity variants and other Electric types. Togekiss can even provide Defog and Heal Bell support, while Galarian Weezing can handle most Knock Off users. Powerful physical attackers such as Heracross, Darmanitan, Alolan Marowak, and Swords Dance Cobalion can take advantage of Porygon2's inability to generally threaten them. The aforementioned Togekiss and Galarian Weezing fare well against Heracross, while Suicune and Milotic can take on Darmanitan and Alolan Marowak. Healthy Noivern can switch directly into Cobalion and any Noivern can outspeed Heracross and Alolan-Marowak should Porygon2 predict their switch in with Teleport.

Raikou.overview:
The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

Raikou is an amazing pivot and sweeper in the RU tier, being one of the fastest Pokemon and having great power and coverage. It can pivot easily with Volt Switch while pressuring many Electric-immune Pokemon that may try to block it. Its decent bulk lets it take some hits to offensively check foes or set up more easily. Its typing and movepool also make it a good offensive check to most Flying- and Water-types as well as some Electric-types, including Togekiss, Suicune, Milotic, and Xurkitree. Raikou has to compete with other Electric-type Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Toxtricity as both a pivot and a wallbreaker, however. It has no moves to hit Seismitoad and Gastrodon, and it has a hard time breaking through some Electric-resistant Pokemon such as Roserade and Dragalge. It also struggles to beat bulky special walls such as Umbreon and Registeel, and it lacks the power to KO most threats without boosts or some prior damage.
Raikou.comments:
Other Options

Extrasensory can be used to hit Poison-types that wall Raikou otherwise, such as Dragalge, Roserade, Toxtricity, and Vileplume, and it does more damage to Fighting-types like Mienshao and Heracross. Raikou can use Choice Specs or Choice Scarf to act more as a wallbreaker or a revenge killer; however, Heavy-Duty Boots is generally better, as it allows Raikou to switch its moves and keep itself healthy more easily throughout the match. Raikou can be used on rain teams alongside Politoed as a good Electric-type check, and it can use Thunder as its main STAB move and Weather Ball over Scald on these teams.

Checks and Counters

Seismitoad and Gastrodon: Raikou doesn't have any coverage to threaten Water / Ground types such as Seismitoad and Gastrodon, although they have to be careful with Toxic, especially Seismitoad, as it lacks any form of reliable recovery.

Special Walls: Special walls such as Umbreon, Porygon2, and Registeel don't fear much from Raikou, as they take little damage from its moves, but they have to be careful of Volt Switch constantly chipping them throughout the match. Porygon2 is also susceptible to Toxic and can be used as setup fodder by Calm Mind + Substitute Raikou.

Dragon-types: Dragon-types such as Regidrago and Dragalge tank Raikou's attacks easily and can deal a lot of damage in return with their STAB moves, though Dragalge has to be careful of potential Extrasensory.

Poison-types: Some Poison-types, such as Vileplume and Roserade, take little damage from Raikou, as they have good Special Defense, resist most of its coverage, and are immune to Toxic. Toxtricity also resists most of Raikou's attacks, and it has sound moves to bypass a potential Substitute, but it takes much more damage from Raikou due to its mediocre defensive stats. The uncommon Extrasensory Raikou can do more damage to them.

Faster Revenge Killers: Despite Raikou's high Speed and overall good bulk, some revenge killers can outspeed and beat it. Choice Scarf Darmanitan and Choice Scarf Tyrantrum can OHKO Raikou, whereas Choice Scarf Mienshao and Choice Scarf Heracross can OHKO it after little damage. They have to be careful with Substitute, although Mienshao and Darmanitan can use U-turn to break it. Noivern with Draco Meteor can revenge kill a weakened Raikou, even through Substitute thanks to Infiltrator, and it can take a hit from Raikou if needed.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description: Volt Switch is used to pivot, whereas Thunderbolt is used when Raikou needs more damage. Aura Sphere does more damage to most Steel-types while also 2HKOing Zarude and KOing Tyrantrum after some damage. Toxic punishes Electric immunities like Gastrodon and Seismitoad. Scald can be used over Toxic to hit some Ground- and Fire-types, most notably 2HKOing Rhyperior and Alolan Marowak. Heavy-Duty Boots allows Raikou to pivot as much as possible. This set pairs well with Pokemon that can force out special walls that often switch into Raikou such as Registeel, Porygon2, and Umbreon. Some examples are Heracross, Mienshao, and Cobalion. Other physical wallbreakers like Zarude and Darmanitan can also help pressure Raikou's switch-ins. Noivern can form a great VoltTurn core with Raikou on offensive teams, as the pair provides some defensive utility and counterplay to faster threats, with Noivern also pressuring some of Raikou's best checks in Seismitoad, Roserade, and Dragalge. Klefki, Heracross, and Roserade can use Spikes to help Raikou weaken foes through pivoting, and Raikou can pressure most entry hazard control options in return.

sets.name: Calm Mind
sets.description: Aura Sphere hits Dark-, Normal-, and Steel-types like Zarude, Umbreon, Porygon2, and Stakataka. Scald hits Alolan Marowak and Rhyperior, which easily stop Raikou otherwise. Substitute lets Raikou punish Pokemon that can't do much against it, especially after boosts, such as Porygon2, Milotic, and Togekiss, letting it find more setup opportunities or better pressure opposing teams. Leftovers gives Raikou passive recovery, allowing it to set up more easily after taking damage or using Substitute. Heavy-Duty Boots can be used with three attacks to give Raikou an easier time acting as a wallbreaker and revenge killer throughout the match. Raikou can potentially stall out attacking moves with Pressure, especially if using Substitute. This set goes well with other special wallbreakers, such as Starmie and Choice Specs Sylveon, which can help Raikou pressure and weaken bulkier special walls such as Registeel and Umbreon. Other wallbreakers such as Heracross and Mienshao can pressure Raikou's checks; in return, Raikou can check bulkier Flying- and Water-types that give them trouble. Spikes support from the likes of Roserade, Klefki, and Heracross helps Raikou weaken its checks. Grass-types such as Zarude and the aforementioned Roserade can help deal with Seismitoad and Gastrodon, which are some of the best checks to this set.

Entei.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Choice Band
sets.description:
Entei is a strong wallbreaker that can also act as a good revenge killer and a decent late-game cleaner thanks to its strong priority move. Sacred Fire is Entei's best STAB move due to its great Base Power, no drawback unlike Flare Blitz, and especially high burn chance. Extreme Speed allows Entei to revenge kill weakened faster threats such as Raikou, Starmie, and Sharpedo. Stone Edge deals heavy damage to Fire-types such as Chandelure, Incineroar, and Volcanion, which take Entei's STAB moves well. It is also Entei's best move for Water-types and OHKOes Noivern. The slightly higher Base Power of Flare Blitz allows Entei to OHKO Registeel and Raikou as well as consistently 2HKO Reuniclus and specially defensive Porygon2. Stomping Tantrum can be used over Flare Blitz to 2HKO Dragalge, Tyrantrum, and Diancie as well as hitting Rhyperior for more damage. A Jolly nature is necessary to outspeed Obstagoon, Darmanitan, Indeedee, and Mimikyu. Inner Focus prevents Incineroar from lowering Entei's Attack stat with Intimidate.

Entei's best counters are bulky Water-types such as Milotic, Suicune, and Seismitoad. As a result, a strong Grass-type or Electric-type like Dhelmise, Roserade, Toxtricity, or Xurkitree is extremely important as a teammate. These four examples are also able to threaten or wear down bulky Rock-types like Diancie and Gigalith, which are huge threats to Entei too, especially if Entei lacks Stomping Tantrum. In return, Entei can threaten their counters such as Registeel for Roserade's case or Crobat for Dhelmise. A Fighting-type such as Cobalion or Mienshao can help Entei with bulky Rock-types as well as Curse Snorlax. These two can also bring Entei safely on the field via U-Turn or Volt Switch. In general, Entei appreciates VoltTurn support a lot. Entei is easily revenge killed by other Pokemon once it's locked into a move, so a defensive backbone provided by bulky PokÃ©mon like Seismitoad, Stakataka, and Assault Vest Reuniclus is helpful. An entry hazard remover like Noivern, Crobat, and Starmie is crucial due to Entei's weakness to Stealth Rock. Speaking of hazards, Entei appreciates Spikes or Toxic Spikes setters such as Roserade, Golisopod, Galarian Weezing and Dragalge alongside the usual Stealth Rock, because they support Entei in wearing down its counters as well as general wallbreaking. Lastly, although Entei is a decent late-game cleaner due to its strong Extreme Speed, a more reliable one like Choice Scarf Heracross, Calm Mind Raikou, or Shift Gear Toxtricity is a solid partner too.

sets.name: Substitute + Calm Mind
sets.description:
Subtitute + Calm Mind Suicune relies on Pressure to wage a war of attrition on a number of Pokemon that can wall it such as Seismitoad, Gastrodon, and Mantine. Calm Mind makes it very hard for special attackers to break Suicune's Substitute and makes Scald much harder to switch into. Substitute provides Suicune with a way to protect itself from status effects, which will cripple sets lacking Rest, and is especially effective for PP stalling Pokemon unable to break its substitute in one hit. Note that Suicune must still be cautious not to switch into status moves like Toxic and Thunder Wave from the likes of Registeel, Togekiss, and Klefki. Protect enables Suicune to scout Choice item users, stall out low PP moves, and gain additional Leftovers recovery. Ice Beam can be used to hit the likes of Zarude and Seismitoad after boosting, which are otherwise major threats. Roar is another option that allows Suicune to phaze out other setup sweepers and rack up entry hazard damage. The EV spread allows Suicune to outpace base 80 Speed Pokemon like Chandelure and Togekiss, while giving it an 81% chance that Seismitoad's Earthquake will not break its Substitute. An alternative spread with maximum Speed will allow Suicune to Speed tie with Heracross, but lowers its chances of its Substitute surviving Seismitoad's Earthquake to about 56%. This set lacks recovery other than Leftovers, so Suicune must be careful not to take Knock Off from Pokemon like Incineroar and Obstagoon without a Substitute up. Suicune must also be careful not to get hit by Trick from the likes of Darmanitan and Gardevoir, as it completely cripples this set.

Suicune's natural bulk and typing make it a great choice for teams looking to check threats like Darmanitan, Alolan Marowak, and Metagross. Suicune's best check is Zarude, which can use Jungle Healing to remove any Scald burns and threaten Suicune with Power Whip. Therefore, it pairs well with Zarude checks like Cobalion, Galarian Weezing, and Togekiss. Cobalion has the added bonus of being an excellent Knock Off absorber thanks to Justified, while Galarian Weezing and Togekiss check other threats to Suicune like certain Guts Fighting-types such as Machamp and Heracross. The aforementioned Guts users, along with Obstagoon, pose a notable threat to Suicune because they are powerful enough to threaten Suicune and unafraid of burns from Scald. Sylveon or Togekiss notably can provide Heal Bell support to remedy this set's weakness to status effects. Suicune is also threatened by Electric-types like Xurkitree, Toxtricity, and Raikou, so it should be used alongside Electric-type checks such as Roserade, Assault Vest Reuniclus, Zarude, and Vileplume. Finally, Suicune lacking Roar is unable to beat certain Calm Mind sweepers with Psyshock like Reuniclus and Sigilyph, so it is wise to pair it with checks to them like Obstagoon and Chandelure.

sets.name: RestTalk
sets.description:
This Suicune set is capable of sweeping given the right conditions. Rest allows this set to be extremely resilient to status and provides it with reliable recovery. Sleep Talk prevents Suicune from being passive while using Rest. Roar can be used over Sleep Talk in order to more reliably defeat other Calm Mind sweepers like Reuniclus and rack up entry hazard damage. This set runs enough Speed EVs to outpace Adamant Golurk and Jolly Alolan Marowak, then invests the rest in Defense and HP to be as hard to break through as possible. This, along with reliable recovery in Rest, makes it a much better answer to the likes of Darmanitan, Sharpedo, Cobalion, and Stakataka.

Rest renders this set much less vulnerable to status effects and Knock Off, but it still has one major nemesis in the meta: Zarude. Zarude can use Jungle Healing to easily remove Scald burns, and this set lacks the safety net of Substitute to allow moves like Ice Beam to be effective. Checks to Zarude include Pokemon like Cobalion, Incineroar, Crobat, Noivern, and Togekiss. This set has difficulty setting up Calm Mind against offensive Electric-types like Xurkitree, Raikou, Heliolisk, and Toxtricity, so checks like Roserade, Zarude, Celebi, and Porgyon2 work well with it. Heliolisk has the added danger of Dry Skin causing Water-type moves to heal it, so Suicune must be played particularly carefully against it. If running Roar, Suicune can phaze foes into Spikes provided by Roserade, making it a particularly notable partner.

Celebi.overview: The following analysis is outdated and is currently being revamped. Information contained in the analysis may be misinformative in regards to the current SS RU metagame.

sets.name: Utility
sets.description:
Celebi serves as a decent utility option for balanced teams thanks to its natural bulk, reliable recovery, ability in Natural Cure, and Speed tier. It also serves as a reliable switch-in to Xurkitree and Raikou. Thunder Wave lets it paralyze common threats like Noivern and Necrozma. U-turn allows Celebi to pivot on common switch-ins to it like Togekiss and Metagross to give its team momentum. Psychic hits Pokemon that otherwise freely switch into Celebi like Noivern and Roserade. Grass Knot hits Ground-type threats like Steelix harder so Celebi can spread paralysis more effectively and beats Water-types like Milotic.

U-turn from threats like Mienshao and Darmanitan easily forces Celebi out. Therefore, teammates like Galarian Weezing, Togekiss, and Cobalion are appreciated to absorb it. These same teammates can come in on Golisopod, which can OHKO Celebi. Wallbreaking teammates like Chandelure, Mienshao, and Guts Heracross can take advantage of Celebi pivoting on Steel-types and special walls like Metagross, Stakataka, and Umbreon. A partner like Milotic to check Fire-types like Chandelure, Volcanion, and Darmanitan takes pressure off of Celebi.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Celebi has a niche on balance and bulky offense teams thanks to its Speed tier, utility moves in U-turn and Trick, and ability in Natural Cure. It's also able to check Electric-types like Raikou and Xurkitree with little to no issue. Trick cripples common switch-ins to Celebi like Inciniroar, Togekiss, and Registeel. U-turn lets Celebi pivot on switch-ins like Incineroar and Metagross, and gives its team momentum.

Despite being one of the faster Choice Scarf users, Celebi is vulnerable to Choice Scarf Mienshao. Partners like Togekiss and Galarian Weezing can take any move that either threat has to offer. Additionally, both can provide Defog support, since Celebi is susceptible to entry hazards as it pivots. A partner like Heracross or Swords Dance Cobalion that can take advantage of Celebi's U-turn is appreciated. Threats like Incineroar, Metagross, and Snorlax can take advantage of Celebi being locked into an attack. Milotic, Rhyperior, and the aforementioned Cobalion make good teammates to handle such foes. These same teammates also appreciate Celebi coming in to absorb Scald.

sets.name: Belly Drum
sets.description:
Linoone is a fearsome sweeper with Belly Drum alongside STAB Extreme Speed, but it is held back by its difficulty setting up and the prevalence of Cobalion. Stomping Tantrum allows Linoone to heavily damage Steel-types like Registeel, Steelix, and Stakataka, but Cobalion will outspeed and KO Linoone before it can use it. Seed Bomb hits bulky Water-type Pokemon like Seismitoad, Milotic, and Suicune for greater damage than Extreme Speed, and also 2HKOes Quagsire, which can otherwise wall Linoone easily by ignoring its boosts with Unaware. Alternatively, Throat Chop hits Pokemon like Dhelmise, Cresselia, and Reuniclus while potentially letting Linoone set up on Sylveon and Toxitricity. Play Rough is another option that gives Linoone a better matchup against Bewear and Umbreon. Linoone should customize its moveset with these moves based on its team's needs. Linoone runs enough Speed to outpace Chandelure.

Linoone's all-or-nothing nature and lack of defensive utility make it work best on hyper offense teams. Cobalion is Linoone's most widely used and consistent answer, easily surviving a +6 Extreme Speed and OHKOing back with Close Combat, so Linoone should be paired with Cobalion checks like Crobat, Chandelure, and Golisopod. Linoone can set up much more easily with dual screens or Aurora Veil support from Pokemon like Xatu, Klefki, and Alolan Ninetales. Alolan Ninetales also provides hail support for Arctozolt, and Arctozolt does a great job at wearing out common Linoone checks like Steelix and Cobalion. Cloyster is another good partner that wears down Cobalion, and it can potentially lure and heavily damage it with Hydro Pump. Steelix and Cobalion are also worn down by Spikes support from Klefki and Golisopod. Finally, Linoone appreciates Memento support from teammates like Gardevoir and Zoroark.

sets.name: Sun Sweeper
sets.description:
Shiftry is the most viable Chlorophyll sweeper in the tier, being able to muscle past common checks to Grass-types and sweep with its near perfect coverage at +2. Solar Blade helps Shiftry wallbreak more effectively if run on full sun teams, although Leaf Blade is more consistent once sun runs out and against other weather teams. Knock Off provides wide neutral coverage, hitting Grass-resistant Pokemon such as Noivern, Metagross, and Chandelure. Low Kick hits most Steel-types harder and has a chance to 2HKO Incineroar. Heat Wave is boosted by sun, hitting Fairy-types like Galarian Weezing and Togekiss neutrally as well as OHKOing Chople Berry Cobalion and Heracross, but it misses out on Incineroar and hits most Low Kick targets such as Registeel for slightly lower damage. Protect is an option that significantly improves Shiftry's matchup against teams that rely on Golisopod to check sun, although it sacrifices a valuable move.

Shiftry only fits on teams with sun setters, so Torkoal or Ninetales is a mandatory partner. Torkoal fits best on full sun teams, providing Stealth Rock and setup opportunities with Yawn, while Ninetales is more of a standalone wallbreaker that can form a semi-sun core with Shiftry. Darmanitan can also take advantage of sun, breaking down the opposing team's defensive structure and bring Shiftry into Water-types with U-turn. Heliolisk can similarly wallbreak under sun and pivot out of Ground-types. Entry hazard removal is necessary, as sun teams will often have multiple hazard-weak Pokemon, and Shiftry can get chipped into KO range of priority moves easily. Defog Noivern is a good utility option for this role, while Xatu can bounce back hazards and pivot with Teleport. Other hazard setters such as Stakataka and Cobalion are needed if running Ninetales.

sets.name: Choice Specs
sets.description:
Gardevoir's good coverage, high Special Attack, and acceptable Speed tier makes it a good Choice Specs user in RU. Focus Blast provides crucial coverage for Steel-types that aren't hit neutrally by Gardevoir's STAB moves, such as Registeel, Stakataka, and Steelix. Shadow Ball hits Assault Vest Reuniclus, Metagross, and Doublade, having near-perfect coverage alongside its STAB attacks and Focus Blast. Mystical Fire hits Klefki harder and is more accurate, but the power loss is very notable, failing to 2HKO Registeel and OHKO Steelix after Sturdy is broken. Psyshock can be used to hit Snorlax hard with a STAB move, but it is overall weaker, especially against physically bulky threats such as Cobalion and Seismitoad. Trace is the preferred ability to grab useful abilities from opposing Pokemon, such as Regenerator from Mienshao, Punk Rock from Toxtricity, and Water Absorb from Seismitoad and Volcanion.

Choice Specs Gardevoir's wallbreaking prowess can be taken advantage of by a myriad of Pokemon that thrive late-game. This includes Pokemon such as Xurkitree and Choice Scarf Heracross. The latter two are capable of bashing through Steel-types, which is a good trait considering Gardevoir can sometimes struggle to break through them alone. Gardevoir is also quite frail, and it can struggle to properly switch into battle sometimes. Pivots such as Choice Scarf Mienshao, Zarude, and Crobat are good teammates that are capable of bringing Gardevoir in safely. The latter two are capable of teaming up with Gardevoir to eventually beat down Steel-types that don't have a reliable recovery option, such as Metagross, Registeel, and Stakataka, while Mienshao can just outright force them out. Spikes setters like Klefki, Roserade, and Golisopod are another very useful way to pile on the damage to Steel-types. Knock Off support from the likes of Seismitoad and Incineroar can also be useful, as it removes Assault Vest from Reuniclus, Eviolite from Porygon2, Leftovers from Steel-types like Registeel and Metagross, and Heavy-Duty Boots from Zarude and Incineroar. This allows Gardevoir to make more progress against these threats, as the former two will take more damage from Gardevoir and the latter two will be more vulnerable to cumulative chip damage, therefore making it easier for Gardevoir to break past them.

sets.name: Choice Scarf
sets.description:
Choice Scarf Gardevoir's main niche comes from its access to useful utility moves in Trick and Healing Wish, which give it a notable advantage over other Choice Scarf users in the tier like Mienshao, Heracross, Xurkitree, and Darmanitan. Trick allows Gardevoir to cripple defensive Steel-types such as Registeel, Steelix, and Stakataka. Healing Wish can be especially useful when paired with a strong, frail wallbreaker or a defensive teammate that lacks a consistent form of recovery. Memento can also be useful to give a teammate such as Barbaracle, Cloyster, or Linoone a setup opportunity. Teleport is also very good when paired with a wallbreaker that threatens Steel-types, as Gardevoir has a tendency to lure them in. Gardevoir can also use Mystical Fire over a utility move in order to hit Metagross, Steelix, and Doublade, but these utility moves give Choice Scarf Gardevoir its niche. Trace allows Gardevoir to copy useful abilities such as Regenerator from Mienshao, Adaptability from Dragalge, Storm Drain from Gastrodon, and Beast Boost from Stakataka and Xurkitree. It also gives Gardevoir an excellent matchup against weather teams, as it can copy the Speed boosting abilities from the weather sweepers and revenge kill them as a result.

Choice Scarf Gardevoir is a very good partner for powerful wallbreakers that are prone to being worn down throughout the course of a match. Alolan Marowak, Reckless variants of Mienshao, and Chandelure are all powerful wallbreakers that get worn down by entry hazards and can be crippled by assorted status moves. Healing Wish can heal these Pokemon back to full; many teams are not equipped to deal with these dangerous Pokemon getting what is essentially an extra life. These wallbreakers, as well as others such as Heracross and Bewear, all threaten the Steel-types that might prevent Gardevoir from cleaning late-game. Gardevoir can further help these Pokemon out by revenge killing threats to them, such as Zarude, Obstagoon, and Toxtricity. Pivots such as Noivern, Mienshao, Darmanitan, and Zarude can help Gardevoir to get into battle safely. Gardevoir is rather slow for a Choice Scarf user, so it can't revenge kill most other Choice Scarf users in the tier. Having defensive answers to Choice Scarf users such as Heracross, Xurkitree, and Darmanitan is therefore useful. Heracross can be hindered with Flying-types such as Togekiss and Crobat, Xurkitree can be pressured via Ground-types like Steelix and Seismitoad or Electric-types such as Raikou, and Darmanitan is annoyed by Water-types like Suicune, Milotic, Volcanion, and Seismitoad. A user of strong priority, such as Golisopod, can also help remedy this issue.

sets.name: Offensive Pivot
sets.description:
Ninjask is a niche option usable as an offensive pivot with its amazing Speed and access to STAB U-turn, being able to revenge kill most threats on offense and provide free switches to wallbreakers against bulkier teams. However, due to its mediocre base Attack, horrible bulk, lack of coverage options, and underwhelming STAB combination, Ninjask needs a lot of team support for it to work, as it is very easily checked. Its typing does, however, allow it to switch into some Grass-, Fighting-, and Ground-type moves if necessary, but most of the time it risks being hit by any coverage move, which will deal a significant amount of damage. Swords Dance allows Ninjask to be a late-game cleaner and Protect allows it to safely increase its Speed with Speed Boost and outspeed everything in the tier, including Choice Scarf users such as Mienshao and Flygon, as well as Jolly Barraskewda. 156 EVs on Speed allow Ninjask to outspeed Choice Scarf Metagross and 130 base Speed Pokemon such as Crobat and Aerodactyl. A spread with 44 HP / 252 Atk / 212 Spe can be used to outspeed Jolly Barraskewda without needing to use Protect at the cost of some bulk.

Wallbreakers like Mienshao, Golurk, and Salazzle love Ninjask's capacity to lure in and use U-turn to pivot out of Steel-types. Other offensive pivots help Ninjask pressure the opponent, such as Raikou, Flygon, Noivern, and Mienshao, while defensive pivots such as Incineroar, Porygon2, and Milotic can switch into Ninjask's checks and use their slow pivoting moves to give Ninjask more opportunities to come in. Entry hazard support helps Ninjask weaken the opposing team, which it needs due to its poor coverage. Seismitoad, Cobalion, and Stakataka are good Stealth Rock setters; Cobalion is also able to use Volt Switch to carry momentum and safely bring in Ninjask. Golisopod and Roserade can set Spikes for it, and Golisopod also has Knock Off to remove Leftovers or Heavy-Duty Boots from Ninjask's checks. Roserade, on the other hand, helps deal with Electric- and Water-types that can be an issue for Ninjask.

sets.name: Physical Cleaner
sets.description:
Sharpedo's Speed Boost, good coverage, and nice offensive stats and typing make it a threatening late-game cleaner that Choice Scarf users are often unable to revenge kill.
